Award.AbstractNarration:
Processes of Knowledge Co-production for Adaptation Decision-making in Semi-Arid Regions

This two-year project, undertaken by a biologist/science policy scholar, a geographer, and two graduate students from the University of Colorado, will document how knowledge is currently produced, articulated, represented, transmitted, and incorporated within coping and adaptation decisions by actors in semi-arid regions.

Their results promise to provide the means for better integrating scientific and local knowledge so as to improve decision-making regarding asset management and allocation of resources among those engaged in animal husbandry. Results will also be shared with policy makers and scientists.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Many countries and regions are investing in projects that have the goal of bringing climate and weather information to populations that are at risk of damage to life and property from extreme events and long term changes in climate. These efforts, known as ?climate services? recognize that it is important to understand what will be useful to people managing resources or making other decisions that are sensitive to weather and climate, and that to know what is useful, it is necessary to work together with them in the development and dissemination of scientific information.  This process is known as ?co-production? of knowledge or science in practice, and can have different meanings and ways of being implemented. Organizations interested in improving the resilience of communities and businesses on the ground are increasingly attempting to work with local communities to co-produce knowledge together to make it more usable in practice. Many of these co-production projects are now being implemented all over the world. However, what hasn?t been examined much to date is how co-production works in practice in situations where there is a very different approach to generating knowledge and where there are built-in differences in power and access to the processes that bring people together to co-produce knowledge.

 

In our project, we studied knowledge co-production projects among international organizations, national government agencies, and agro-pastoralists in Tanzania.  The processes we studied involved a group of people called Maasai, who are primarily pastoralists, managing livestock such as cattle and goats in a very arid environment with strong seasonality. They also practice small-scale agriculture. Maasai have specific ways of gathering data and information about their environment to support the decisions they make grazing and farming, along with other decisions vital to sustaining their livelihoods and wellbeing. Due to shifts in the climate, as well as ongoing social changes, many Maasai are finding that some signs in the environment are less reliable indicators then they used to be. At the same time, the meteorological agency of Tanzania, TMA, was tasked with implementing and participating in several co-production processes to try to see how scientific information could be made more usable to pastoralists and other actors across the landscape in Tanzania. These co-production processes were funded by international funding agencies working in Tanzania.

 

We found that as these processes were carried out, the effectiveness of co-production was often reduced because of existing differences in worldviews, as well as different criteria regarding what constituted valid knowledge, and power differentials that meant that there was unequal access to shaping the process of co-production. As a result, certain actors with more power in the process (who were nonetheless insecure about their status) did not fully engage in understanding what would be relevant to local people, learning how knowledge was credible to others, or understanding the value of sources of knowledge other than their own.  

 

While our research has interesting implications for the scholarly community studying co-production processes, it also has broader impact for the community of national and international organizations trying to implement co-production successfully. At the conclusion of the project, we convened a 2-day workshop with stakeholders from local to national levels in Tanzania to share and discuss results. Along with this, we produced a summary of research findings and distributed bound copies to all workshop participants. Additionally, through invited presentations at the World Meteorological Organization, the Indian Meteorological Department, and India-UK Water Centre, results were shared with climate services practitioners. Additionally, some findings of this research were taken up within co-production principles developed for national meteorological services by the UK Met Office. As co-production continues to gain attention globally, we hope that our results will be of importance to these groups in the future.
